awd_titl_txt: NSF/ENG/ECCS-BSF: Self-Assembled Superlattice Nanowires: A Pathway to High Efficiency Thermoelectrics
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract:
Non-technical: As developing countries continue to industrialize, energy demands are rapidly increasing; thus, there is an increasing need for sustainable clean energy sources driven by scientific research.  Typically, the efficiency of energy-production and utilization systems is limited by heat loss; conversion of the wasted heat into usable energy may be accomplished using solid-state devices that convert heat to electricity, i.e. thermoelectrics.  Thermoelectric generators are used to power satellites, probes, and rovers, but their widespread terrestrial use would require increased device efficiencies.  This project explores a pathway towards high efficiency thermoelectrics using a naturally occurring phenomenon, spontaneous vertical phase separation, to achieve nanowire superlattices that extend over macroscopic lengths.  The ultimate goal is to understand heat propagation across the superlattices in order to optimize the performance of several advanced nanotechnologies. The project consists of a collaboration between the University of Michigan and Ben-Gurion University, integrating the expertise of the U.S. investigators (theory and thermoelectric characterization) with that of the Israeli investigators (nanowire fabrication and characterization). The new knowledge gained will be broadly disseminated through publications and presentations, and curriculum development. Outreach activities emphasize the mentoring of women and underrepresented minorities.
Technical Description: Nanometer-scale heterostructured materials have been identified as promising candidates for high efficiency thermoelectric devices. In the framework of the phonon-glass-electron crystal concept, the thermoelectric efficiency can be enhanced by reducing dimensionality, through the formation of two-dimensional thin films or superlattices, one-dimensional nanowires, or zero-dimensional quantum dots.  Indeed, one-dimensional conductors, in which electrons are restricted to a narrow energy range, are predicted to enable conversion efficiencies approaching the Carnot limit. A primary goal of the project is to explore eutectic alloy catalyst-induced vertical phase separation during vapor-liquid-solid growth of nanowires.  In addition to developing predictive understanding of these mechanisms, nanowire superlattices extending over macroscopic length-scales will be fabricated, and spatially-resolved Seebeck measurements will be demonstrated using scanning thermoelectric microscopy. Finally, new understanding of the mechanisms for enhanced thermoelectric figure of merit in nanowires will be developed.  In particular, correlations between van Hove singularities in the density of states and enhancements of the Seebeck coefficient will be investigated using both doping and electrostatic gating to tune the Fermi level of the nanowires. The combined expertise of the team in nanowire growth, structural and thermoelectric characterization, and device simulation and fabrication will be used to develop a pathway to superlattice nanowires for thermoelectric generators.

por.por_cntn:
Overview 

Nanometer-scale heterostructures are promising candidates for thermoelectric (TE) devices with high figure-of-merit, ZT=S2σT/κ, where S is the Seebeck coefficient (thermopower), T is the temperature, and σ (κ) is the electrical (thermal) conductivity. Most approaches to increase S lead to a decrease in σ, while increasing σ tends to increase κ. Using the phonon-glass-electron crystal concept, ZT can be increased by reducing dimensionality, via the formation of thin films or superlattices (SLs), one-dimensional (1D) nanowires (NW), or zero-dimensional quantum dots.  Indeed, 1D conductors, in which electrons are restricted to a narrow energy range, are predicted to enable TE efficiencies approaching the Carnot limit.  Of particular interest is the enhanced TE power factor enabled by resonant tunneling of carriers through double barrier heterostructures such as those in NW SLs.  Although NW heterostructure growth is established, artificial SL NWs has only been demonstrated using alternating laser pulses. We proposed instead to use the spontaneous self-assembly of SLs during NW growth, especially those which provide a pathway to macroscopic-length NWs for high efficiency TE. 

Intellectual Merit

In this project, we aimed to exploit a naturally occurring phenomenon, spontaneous phase separation, to achieve NW SLs with lengths extending over macroscopic length-scales. We aimed to utilize our combined expertise in NW growth, structural and thermoelectric characterization, and device simulation and fabrication to develop and characterize NW SL heterostructures with high TE efficiency. To this end, we explored eutectic alloy catalyst-induced vertical phase separation during vapor-liquid-solid growth of NWs.  In addition to developing predictive understanding of these mechanisms, we aimed to fabricate NW SLs extending over macroscopic length-scales, and demonstrate spatially-resolved Seebeck measurements using scanning thermoelectric microscopy.  

To gain understanding of the physics underlying this self-assembly process, we compared two main material systems. The study of each material system was led by one of the groups with participation of the other. The UM group led the study of In-Sn-O system, while the BGU group led the study of the In-Zn-O system. In addition, various aspects of the physics were also studied and verified on various other material systems. At the end of this project, we claim to have reached a complete understanding of the cause for the spontaneous formation of SL in nanowires. A model describing how and why SL nanowires form will be submitted for publication as part of a joint full review paper on the subject.  Finally, this work has opened up a new direction for nanowire heterostructures, wherein we are exploring nanowire polytype selection during molecular-beam epitaxy.

Broader Impacts

      The project was a collaboration between UM and BGU, with frequent communication via e-mail, skype, and Zoom. The BGU team visited the Michigan team twice during the grant period.  During the 5 years of this project, 7 graduate, 16 undergraduate, and 3 high school students participated in the research, leading to 11 publications, 3 submitted (or to-be-submitted) manuscripts, 29 conference presentations, and 10 invited presentations.  The cohort included 9 female and 3 URM students, including 2 female graduate students (including 1 who is also URM), 5 female undergraduate students, and 2 female high school students. All students learned about novel semiconducting nanostructures and their importance for electronic and thermoelectric device applications.  Most graduate students presented papers at national conferences before the end of their first year of graduate school.  The graduate students were encouraged to apply for both conference travel and research travel funds through the Rackham graduate school.  In addition, Ms. H. Lu was able to visit Brookhaven National Laboratory for research activities through an "INTERN" supplement.  A significant percentage of the undergraduate students who have participated in this project enrolled in graduate school following their graduation.  Two doctoral students received PhDs in Materials  Science; both are employed at Fortune 500 companies.
